info.title: Consumer Account APIs Specifications
info.description:
## Introduction Explore the world of opportunities and empower customers with our APIs
Empower customers to interact with your interface for different banking needs while we help you orchestrate it using our APIs.

There are 11 API services in this group for Consumer Account APIs.
1. Account Details to retrieve details of an account
2. Account Listing to retrieve the list of accounts related to an account holder
3. Account Transactions to retrieve transactions of an account
4. Account Contacts to retrieve contact related details of an account
5. Account Addresses to retrieve account address details of an account
6. Account Balance to retrieve the balance details of an account
7. Account Risks to retrieve the risk details of an account
8. Account Status to retrieve the status details of an account
9. Account Limits to retrieve the limit details of an account
10. Account Deposit to retrieve customer fixed deposit details of an account
11. Account Deposit Profile to retrieve account deposit details of an account
## Encryption and Signing Encryption and Signing uses JSON Web Tokens (JWT), an open industry standard RFC7519 method to represent claims securely across two parties. ### Algorithms SCB provides support for the beLow-mentioned algorithms, which are specified in the JOSE Header, as per JSON Web Signature (JWS) and JSON Web Encryption (JWE) Standards.
Standard Algorithm JOSE Header
JSON Web Signature (JWS) ES256 kid: (key id) cty: JWS alg: ES256
JSON Web Encryption (JWE) RSA-OAEP-256 (Asymmetric) kid: (key id) cty: JWT alg: RSA-OAEP-256
## Guide for JWE and JWS As per SCB API Security standards, SCB uses Compact Serialization for its JWS/JWE representation. The content to be sent to the client is first signed folLowing JWS specifications and then encrypted and sent as a JWE to the client. Specifics for creating each component are as shown beLow: ### JSON Web Signature The folLowing describes the structure of our JWS. **Message** : Content to be sent to client **JWS Payload** : BASE64URL-ENCODE(Message) **Signature** : ASCII(BASE64URL-ENCODE(UTF8(JOSE Header))‘.’BASE64URL-ENCODE(JWS Payload)) **Structure** : BASE64URL(UTF8(JOSE Header))‘.’BASE64URL(JWS Payload)‘.’BASE64URL(JWS Signature)
### JSON Web Encryption The folLowing describes the structure of our JWE. The payload in our JWE is the JWS we have created in the steps above. The JOSE header of JWE contains both symmetric and asymmetric encryptions. Symmetric encryption to encrypt the payload, and assymetric encryption to encrypt the symmetric key. The assymetric keypair belongs to the client who will be receiving the JWE. **JWE Payload** : JWS Signature (from above) **JWE Ciphertext** : *ENCRYPT-SYMMETRIC*(JWE Payload) **JWE Encrypted Key** : *ENCRYPT-ASYMMETRIC*(Symmetric Key) - using client's public key **Structure** : BASE64URL-ENCODE(UTF8(JWE Header))‘.’BASE64URL-ENCODE(JWE Encrypted Key)‘.’BASE64URL-ENCODE(JWE Initialization Vector)‘.’BASE64URL-ENCODE(JWE Ciphertext)‘.’BASE64URL-ENCODE(JWE Authentication Tag) ## API Response Codes
Response Code Response Message HTTP status
E001 Field is mandatory 400
E002 Field value not in valid range 400
E003 Invalid Format 400
E004 Contains invalid characters 400
E005 Resource not found 404
E006 No unique resource found 400
E100 Unable to decrypt 500
E101 Unable to verify signature 500
E102 Unable to decrypt or verify signature 500
E103 Unable to encrypt 500
E104 Unable to sign 500
E105 Unable to encrypt or sign 500
E110 Invalid MTLS Cert 400
E111 Invalid Token Error 401
E112 Forbidden 403
E200 Downstream System Error 500
E201 Internal API Gateway Error 500
E202 Timeout Error 500
E300 Modify request as message is too large 413
E999 Unexpected error occurred 500

parameters.name: Transaction-Id
parameters.description: Unique transaction reference identifier for the API request, for tracking purposes

parameters.description: IP address which the request originated from, segregated by commas. \<user ip>, \<server ip> etc

parameters.description: Indicate the specific Market or Country for which this operation is performed. Value should be a 2-char ISO-3166 country code.

parameters.name: posting-start-date
parameters.description: Specifies the start date for filtering out the transactions date in YYYY-MM-DD format only. Accepts a date range of maximum 180 days between posting-start-date and posting-end-date.

parameters.name: posting-end-date
parameters.description: Specifies the end date for filtering out the transactions date in YYYY-MM-DD format only. Accepts a date range of maximum 180 days between posting-start-date and posting-end-date.

parameters.name: last-posting-date
parameters.description: When total transaction count exceed the limit (500), second request is needed. In second request, last received posting date and last received sequence number is required. This value is the posting-date and sequence-number from the previous request's last transaction object. e.g. Assuming 5000 is the total transaction count in the response, make another 9 requests to get the remaining transactions.

parameters.name: last-sequence-number
parameters.description: Refer to above last-posting-date description.
